title: Ticket #2868: Win Profile not unloaded when a jobs is condor_rm'd
description:
When using load_profile = true on Condor 7.6.6, If a job is removed with condor_rm, a warning appears in the Windows Application Log:

"Unable to uload profile condor-reuse-slot1_1"

and the profile directory C:\Documents and Settings\condor-reuse-slot1_1 is never deleted. This causes problems for subsequent jobs run on this slot.

The specific problem reported in the Rust support queue appears to reference a dynamic slot. it is not known at this time if the problem also applies to static slots.

Original text of the rust ticket follows 

We are testing the use of an application, Ansys Workbench with Condor.
The Central Manager/Submit node is a Linux (Centos 5.7 64bit) machine. The
execution nodes uses Windows XP 64 bit.
The Condor version is 7.6.6.

In order to be able to use this application, the user profile has to be
loaded so the setting below has to be added in the submit description
file.
-
Load_profile = True
-

When this setting is specified, the calculation terminates succesfully.

However if the calculation is interrupted by executing condor_rm on the
submit node, a warning "Unable to unload profile condor-reuse-slot1_1"
appears in the Application section of the Event Viewer of Windows. Also
the profile directory "C:\Documents and Settings\condor-reuse-slot1_1"
remains. (In the case the job terminates normally this directory is
deleted by Condor)

This affects the next job being executed on the node. Ansys Workbench
fails to execute it if "C:\Documents and Settings\condor-reuse-slot1_1"was
not deleted.
remarks:
2012-Mar-16 14:22:40 by johnkn:
Subsequent email exchanges via rust indicate that the problem does reproduce with static slots as well as dynamic slots. And that the problem does appear to be caused by a process that is not killed by condor when the job is RM'd.

There is a Ansys WB license client process that is not a child of the starter. We currently suspect that this process has ACL's that prevent the starter from terminating it, the ProcLog shows
